values:
Drawing Jack


I wish I could draw how much I love you.

I would draw the Madonna cuddling & nuzzling pudgy baby fingers.

I would paint colors
Fire engine red
Earthy Compost Brown
Tall Sunflower Yellow
Stiff Denim Blue
Stormy Ocean Gray

I would draw Mountains with bubbling streams and falling jagged rough boulders

I would draw a spiky furred Grizzly swiping sharp nailed paws at threatening enemies

I would draw humming birds sucking pink flower nectar from perfect yellow roses

I would draw the melody of the ABC song sung by a tiny boy voice while hammering white walls

I would draw giggles and tickles and laughter and big wet alligator tears and clinging clenched fists.

I would draw perfect bow pink lips puffing air in and out on my sleeping boys face

I would draw you.

But my heart would melt the paper.

Grief is a slippery nasty beast.  You go about your life, busy, busy, busy.  Then SLAM!  Tears, middle of lunch with brother's said widow, five year old child, widow's new husband, new baby and brother's former neighbor.  I just looked out the window, same view as my brother's dream house next door.  The house where he died.  My neice was counting the sailboats.  But one is missing.  My brother's sailboat.  Sold.  Gone.  Just like him.  I am sure they saw the tears.  Oh well.

Just so you know, the little blurb I wrote on the upcoming amnio is complete shite.  Who really believes the cliche "whatever will be will be".  Certainly not me.  I want this child.  I have seen it suck it's tiny thumb, I have felt it do summersaults for minutes on end, I have nurtured it through it's treacherous first trimester!  Jeez!  If it has downs or some other horrible malformation, I will be devistated.  Utterly, and thouroughly crushed.  Don't believe a thing I write.  God, who was typing that?  Pollyanna?  Miss-I-trust-the-universe?  Ugh!  Make myself ill sometimes.  So, for the record, I am NOT sanguine.  Ever.

So, we had our 8th ultrasound.  The baby has huge lips like alex, very cute.  he/she was opening his/her mouth over and over.  Alex said, "uh, oh....already talking!  He thinks he is in big trouble....three talkers vs. him.  We have Amnio this week, hoping hoping it is not chromosonally challenged.  We're home free-ish after that.  Pregnancy is just a microcosm for motherhood.  Constant worry, rollercoaster ride of uncertainty mingled with hope and joy and pain.

So my tests came out 'mildly troublesome' and my dr. thinks that an amnio is in order.  At first I was freaked out, but now....well, I would rather know if there is something wrong instead of being surprised.  I wish I had just opted for it in the first place.  The things it can tell you about heart problems and genetic issues are amazing.  And, if nothing is wrong, we will have conclusive evidence of it's gender.  In the end, there are only a few things in this life we actually have control over.  I fought against my own nature for so long, now I just want what is supposed to 'be'.  If I am meant to have two children, I will.  If not, I have a perfect family that I wonder what I did to deserve such perfection.
TBC

It is impossible for me to believe that I have not spoken to my brother in four years.  FOUR YEARS!  How do you go from speaking every other day to ...nothing.  He died suddenly, so it's not like we had a fight and can pick up the phone any month or year and mend fences.  He just vanished!  For 38 years he was my best friend, and then he evaporated into thin air.  Well, not exactly.  We creamated him, so he transformed into some pretty chunky ash.  We burried his ashes under a lovely piece of granite in the Vashon Cemetery.  I know where his remains lie.  But where is he?  Does he exist in another form?   If so, why has he not visited?  

My throat aches from missing him.  My heart constricts when I think of what he is missing.  His little girl is FIVE!  His wife has a new baby boy and a really expensive house and a doctor husband.  I have an amazing husband, a  two year old genious/boy and have another one on the way.  My mom and dad are friends.  Our stepmom (whom my dad left for his German Spinning instructor)is MY best friend....and I could write for years and not fill him in on the joys he is missing.  

Four years.  For the past three anneversaries I have spend caretaking my parents.  This year, I didn't want to see or feel their pain.  It is too intense and wrenching.  So, I took my son to the cemetery to just be where my brother is.  My son  played 'kick the ball' while I cried.  I cried so hard that my little guy ran over to me, put his head on my big tummy, patted me with his hand and said, "I'm sorry mommy, Mommy sad.  Uncle Gregg's house is too small."

My brother would have loved that toddler paragraph.  Maybe he heard it, wherever he is.  I just know that it doesn't get easier with time when someone dies.  It gets more difficult, painful, and heartbreaking.  With every new and lovely chapter in my life, there is a dark and sad knowledge that my brother is missing out again and again.

I may misspell many a word here, no time for correction as I must fit in sleep lately, yet, I must write.

I have a toddler.  A little boy.  It seems like last week I had a baby and now there is this little man coming round the corner with a roll of toilet paper unfurling behind him as he proudly says,"Jack paper, momma!".  He turned two this month.  He is speaking in full sentences and using four syllable words.  He points out different makes of cars such as, "Suburu car", or "Jeep", or "our car".  He knows the name of every piece of construction equipment and he spends hours at his kitchen cooking and tasting and mixing.  I think he is brilliant.

My favorite thing about him is that he loves to dance.  He dances to The Wiggles (if you don't know the group, then you don't have a toddler!) and we do interpretive dance together to classical music.  He comes up with some lovely innovative moves. shakes his little 30 lb frame and giggles and turns, really nothing more delightful in the whole universe.  

After months, I finally found a dance class for two year olds, seems most people like to start dealing with children when thy are three so it was a really tough search.  Thing is, they don't start classes till August.  And I had already told my son we were going to a class to dance with kids on THURSDAY nigh which was tonight.

All week, he has been looking foward to this.  I know because at random moments he will look at me and yell emphatically, "DANCE, KIDS!".

As a substitute, I took him to Ober Park, the only kids park on the island, where they were haveing a free evening concert on the grass.  I thought it would be hippy-centric, full of bad balads and granola eaters.

I was wrong.

It was a feast of lovely Scottish music played on guitar and mandolynn, and a carnival of children playing and dancing on the summer grass.  Older kids were sliding down the steep grassy hills with pieces of card board, younger children ran in the center of the green yelling and laughing and dancing.  All my new friends were clustered around watching their children play in front of them, enjoying adult conversation and home made pop corn.   My little baby squirmed out of my clutches and joined the dancers. I sat with my friends and watched my darling boy become a part of the dance  until he was so exhausted from dancing and laughing that he launched on my lap, cuddled, and watched the 'Songs".

It was my perfect night.  It was my son's dream come true.  I go to bed content that the universe delivered his desire to 'dance with kids'.

Jack, my 20 month old little talker, helped me unload the groceries.  He brought the bag of carrots on his first trip and the bread on his second trip.  With the bread he managed to even get up our three stairs while holding the bread bag and not falling over.  After much praising and hand clapping, I asked him to bring the bread to the kitchen.  

After he went to bed, I was going to make myself a cheese sandwich but could not find the bread!  I looked everywhere, even in his toy baskets.  I gave up and had soup.  Then, just before I went to bed...I found the bread.  He DID put it in the kitchen...his PLAY kitchen.

I love to Internet shop.  I love the shopping blogs that tell you which $200 designer jeans will fit your large ass.  I love the 'story sales blog' that sends you to all the right things to wear for any chick-lit occasion.  I love shopping carts.  Especially the shopping carts that you can fill up and the next time you enter their site, all your lovely things are still right there waiting for you.  I love filling up my shopping cart with a whole new wardrobe and then logging off without spending a dime.  I love re-furnishing my whole house and then saying, nope!  Bye bye!  There is no sales person to disappoint and no cart to ditch.  There is no irritating girl waiting at the entrance to the store with a fake smile plastered on her mall-skin who chirps a chipper hello and expects you to make eye contact and respond to her insincere inanity (is that a word?).  And then...asks if you need help about a hundred times.

I don't have to get dressed.  I don't have to find parking.  I don't have to put on my make-up so a bunch of teenagers won't look at me anyway.  I don't have to get retail overload with all the bad music and flourescent lighting.  I don't have to sneak a peak into one of the 'tilted' Nordstrom mirrors and gasp in horror at the large woman I have become on my ride to the mall (they really do tilt their mirrors to make you look just a bit heavier) and run screaming for the nearest 'slimming outfit' that costs more than I make in a week.

Internet shopping is ninety percent fantasy.  No buyers guilt.  And, when you really, really find a good deal (like my thirty dollar leather steve madden motorcycle boots) you just click a little and it shows up at your door.  Anyone can look good now.  Even if you live on an island with no clothing stores, just like I do.

I give a big thanks to those that invented the world wide web.  My live is better because of you.

Hey,
Hope you and the family are well.  Don't really know how to say this with the proper lead in so, here goes.  We aren't pregnant anymore.  We are doing well.  Physically I am great.  It has been a tough week emotionally and physically.  We had what is called 'blighted ovum' or 'failure to thrive' which just means that the fertilized egg never grew past just that, but my body prepared for it anyway.  

As with most people, It is easy for us to celebrate publicly but we'd rather mourn privately.  It is difficult for me to talk about right now.  I am still getting used to the adjustment in the future. I know that you were excited for us* as well, and had planned to help with the delivery and recovery.  I hope to hold you to that offer of help, we'll just cash in on a later date.  Thank you for your love and prayers.

Christi & Alex

How we told our family.

Tired of the pithy remarks regarding 'God's will' or 'Nature's way of protecting us.'

I have now been on this earth for three years without you.  I am now older than you.  It has been quite an adjustment to be without my history keeper and my protector and my life long best friend.  I shudder to think that you never knew the best version of me.  

You knew me as:

Actress in L.A.
Consumed with Style
Obsessed with my 'Art'
Hungry
Focused on Auditions
dis-interested in our family
Judgemental of anyone not pursuing their 'art'
Starving
Sneaky Smoker
Hungry
Convinced that everyone would be cured if only they would get regular colonics
Broke
Hungry
Bad with money
Selfish and self obsessed
Fickle with friends
Only happy when working as an Actress
Unhappy most of the time
Hungry
Hungry

You would be so proud of me now, I am:

Not an actress
Not Hungry
A very happy mommy
A very proud mommy
A very happy wife
A very in llove wife
A very supportive friend
Full
Sad and sometimes lonley for my brother
Content and fufilled
Connected with our dad
Connected with our mom
Connected with our step mom
Living near home
Full 
Writing
Still selfish because I would like you to know me now.

Sadly, my loss of you is the reason I am dramatically different.  

The world's loss of you is too much to bear.

I hope you are warm.

I hope you are peaceful and happy.

I miss you every single day.

Love,
Your sister

So, I am loosing this baby.  11 weeks, almost through my first trimester.  She's not making it.  They say it is a chromosone thing (parden my terrible spelling).  They say she can't survive because something is so messed up she cannot thrive.  It is most likely not me as I have already carried a child.  

I am not sad Maybe that will come later.  Maybe, I know I am fertile and 40% of pregnancies end in miscarriage in the first trimester.  Maybe I am secretly happy to have a bit more time to be a mom to one baby.  Maybe I am just looking on the bright side so I don't have to be sad.  

O.K., so I am sad.  Sad that there is something dying in me.  Sad that I won't have another little bundle in March.  Sad that I couldn't protect my little fetus.

I need something creative.  Something I can create and express.  Somewhere to put these feelings.

I certainly can't act right now.  Don't even want to.  ick.  

I think I will write.

An essay a day.

An essay a day for 30 days.

Then I will submit the best.

Somewhere.

Somewhere where people will see.

And ... I will start my spoken word pod cast.

Just need a title.

There it is.  I'm committed.  I start tomorrow.  (:).

Just reflecting that when you make the choice to love someone, like a partner, it doubles your chances for heart break. Even if your relationship lasts for the duration. You have the risk of loosing him to cancer, Iraq, or some freak train wreck. If you get to keep him, you then experience together the loss of two sets of parents and extended families. You worry about their work and your work. You worry together about your financial security. You feel responsible for another person. Being single, it is just you and your own worries. If you die...well, firends and family will mourn you but they don't depend on you. It gets even more weighty when you have children. You REALLY worry about them! How will I teach my babies to keep out of traffic or the light sockets? How can I protect them and not smother them? I have a pact with my one year old, he is allowed to leave me but I am not allowed to leave him. When you have babies, they will leave, they need to leave. When you have a child, you are ensuring the deep engulfing sadness of letting go and watching and encouraging the leaving of the creatures you love most. There is still joy in that kind of natural progression of life. But what will I do if something happens to them? What will I and my partner do? Would we survive the loss of our offspring? Would I want to survive at all? No wonder I never stayed with one man. No wonder I was a commitment phobic. No wonder I never wanted children. Until I experienced a loss greater than I could have imagined. Then I realized, no matter how hard you try to sheild your heart from shattering, it still will. So, it is better to just risk it all, experience all life has to offer. Relish the good and endure the pain because it is all a part of the package of life. I am reflecting on this now, as I am 11 weeks pregnant with my second baby. I feel her (?) inside me knitting her sack together, creating cartelidge and bone marrow and brain matter. I am wildly happy. And, I am spotting a bit. Could be nothing. I think I spotted with my fiirst baby. Could be the beginning of another ending and another chance to say good bye. I hope not. I hope I get to say hello for a good long time. But this is life. Life is risky. Love is risky. I am still willing to love this little prune as much as my heart can hold, maybe my love and good nutrition will see it through to birth. And then...well, the only thing that I can do sounds trite, but it is the only thing I can do, take it one day at a time.

My relationship with my brother's ashes began when... well, when he died. The Widow, Allison, did not want to deal with the "Collins' Decision Making Process". So she put my charred brother into six different canisters. One for her, one for mom, one for dad, one for me, one for my step-mom and one for my grandmother. "I'm going to throw him in the water in front of our house, which is what he told me he wanted. I think you all should do the same, but ... I don't want to deal with negotiations, so do what you want." Nice. Sweet. I always thought The Black Widow a bit of a bitch, and now I think I was right. The thought of my brother's charred skin and chunks of bones divided into separate metal tins was revolting. He should be in a big urn somewhere, or spread in the water where he loved to be, or interned in a mausoleum with a nicely engraved stone. Then we could visit him, put fresh flowers in his little vase, chat with/at him, you know...what you do when someone dies suddenly while way too young and you still have so much you want to say and share with them. You need a Place To Go, a Place where you know they are! Most cultures create sacred spaces for the dead, but those spaces are really for the living! When my Grandmother died one year later, her can of Gregg Ashes, for some bizarre reason, went to my step-mom, Katie. Katie, whom my dad left two months before my brother died for a married 50 year-old German aerobics instructor -but that is a whole other story, did not want these ashes as she has been trying to create boundaries regarding the 'Collins Clan'. I don't blame her. She and my brother were very good friends. My brother was horrified that my dad had left her and didn't even know the details. I was the one with the privilege of finally piecing together my dad's jigsaw of deception and lies while on my plane ride home to plan my brother's funeral. I had asked for a seat by the engine so I could cry without attracting attention, but this only gave me too much time to think. I added together over five years of tiny clues my father had left behind, like some warped Hansel and Gretel Fairytale, culminating in the form of a tanned, blond, silicone-boobed fraulein showing up at the hospital with my dad. This 'friend' was "comforting" my father and intruding on my family when the doctor informed Allison and my father that "Gregg did not make it"'. Fortunately, BroomHilde left before Katie showed up to comfort my dad. Back to the ashes. Nana Collins died, and somehow the Ashes ended up with Katie. Katie gave Nana's can of Gregg Ashes back to The Widow, leaving her with only her original Ashes. Dad had his Ashes, Mom had her Ashes. The Widow had hers Dumped Into The Sea. I had yet to receive my allotted dispensation. Then Allison had a memorial 'party' for the Collins' Clan and The Former Friends of Gregg, commemorating the Two Year Anniversary of his death. I had been back in town for a few days when the Event took place. I had my new husband and baby in tow. The Event, (a commerative BRUNCH?!) was uncomfortable at best. Once the Egg, Cheese & Pork Buffet was picked over, no one seemed to know what to talk about. The wives defaulted to their babies. The guys sports. The Collins' Clan ended up looking for some sort of heart-healthy selections amidst the Cholesterol Festival Buffet (my Brother died of a HEART ATTACK! HELLO?!) and huddled together on the couch staring out the window. Cruelly, the sailboat he loved was moored in front of their home, a For Sale sign in the window. Everyone fled as quickly as etiquette would allow. I gravely hung on, trying to wring some meaning out the Event, and was one of the last to go. As we were leaving, arms full of the baby, baby bag, extra baby gear, and a "leftover" untouched salad that had been our contribution to the brunch, the Widow grabbed my arm. "Oh, here..." she reached into the closet to hand me a jar of some kind, "Here's your brother's Ashes." Stunned silence. There was no prelude, no warm up, no gentle "Is this a good time for you?", nothing. After all, that would display empathy and be way too much to ask for from the Black Widow. Then, she trumps herself. "Oh God, the cans leaking! Let me get you a bag for that." Stunned Silence. My jaw is hanging open, I am sure, like some cartoon character. "Here you go...That's better." she says as she hands me a bag for my Brother's Final Resting Place. I look down, and in my numb hand, I am holding grocery bag. Not even a Ziplock. A "Paper or Plastic?" plastic grocery bag from QFC, or Thriftway or Bob's Kwik-Mart. Stunned Silence. My heart is crying. I say "thanks." and stumble out to the car with my brother, or rather, one sixth of him, leaking into my plastic grocery sack. I have kept him in our bed room on the chest of drawers for the past year. Not really in a Place of Honor or anything. Just sort of tucked in behind my jewelry box, where I can see him if I want to, but don't have to. I did take The Ashes out of the plastic bag. And then I started coordinating a burial plan. I told my family that I wanted all of my brother to be in the same place, and in a place where I could visit. This was the only request I have made of my family since my brother died. They all finally agreed, probably thinking that this was part of my Healing Process. As if you heal from your best friend dying. I think you cope. Of all my family, the one with the boundries, Katie, has been the one who helped me find a cemetery and encouraged me in the way of plot choosing and stone selection. She has previous experience in this area, which I guess helps, if not making it easier, than at least the process is more familiar. She has declined to be a part of the 'family ceremony' to be held on the Third Year Anniversary of his death. Guess she is upset there isn't a brunch. Acutally, she didn't really want to see my dad since she has (finally) learned of the years of deception. I understand. We had dinner together one night and talked, and watched my baby son tear into her Tupperware collection. As I got ready to leave with the baby, baby gear, and extra baby stuff, she went to hand me a plastic grocery bag. I paused, sure this couldn't be happening again. "Here, you want to take your Brother's Ashes?" Stunned Silence. My brain shouted "NO! I'm not ready! Haven't you people ever heard of "softening the blow", "easing into", maybe "preamble'?! My mouth, of course, looked like it was in a cartoon again. So I did what anyone does in a situation where you have just been offered your Brother's Ashes in a Plastic Grocery Sack. I lost my keys. Sensing my alarm, my baby decided to pitch a fit that could be heard three blocks away. Struggling towards the car with a screaming baby, searching for the keys, and wanting to refuse the ashes, but not finding the words, Katie snuck by me with a "I need you to take them, Here, I'll just put them in here." I really don't know where 'here' was. Three days later, I heard the garbage truck outside my house. The same as I do every Tuesday morning. Only this particular morning, I had a sudden terrible sinking feeling in my tummy. I ran to my husband. "Umm... Umm..... Honey?, When you cleaned out the car last night, did you find a plastic bag with my brother's ashes in it?" He looked at me blankly, then informed me that he did not clean out the car, that I had cleaned out the car upon arriving home the other night. He looked a question at me. So I ran to the bathroom and threw up. Then I told my husband, "I think I just threw away my brother's ashes and the garbage truck took him away". And...after our mad search of the car and house, our panicked calls to Katie, this was all but confirmed. How do you function when you know that you threw your brother, your best friend's, final remains away with empty jars of baby food, coffee grinds, and dirty diapers? I threw my brother away. I threw my brother in to the garbage. The Garbage truck picked my brother's ashes up with all our other refuse and he is now covered in diapers, rotten food, and plastic. I threw my brother away. My husband comforted me, saying that I 'checked out' when Katie gave me the ashes, so it was not really my fault. Katie comforted me, saying she heard me say 'no' and then gave them to me anyway because she was on her own cleansing mission. My mom comforted me saying that "When Christ comes back, he's going to gather all of us together, our bodies will rise from the dirt and become whole and we will all be joined with Him (christ) and eachother, so don't worry, Honey, his Ashes will rise from the water, from his burial plot, from Liza's tiny locket necklace full of ashes, and now from the dump." My father, I haven't told him yet. Then, some weeks later, the rock in my stomach got a little lighter. I finally thought about my brother and what he would say. I can hear him laughing. Laugh at me, and with me, and about the whole thing. He would just laugh. So...I continue with the arrangements to inter the remaining cans of my brother's bones and skin and hair. I have made a quilt from all his favorite t-shirts. I have a landscaper to manicure the plot. I have green granite for the headstone which will say, "Sweet Gregg, you will be forever missed", I have colluded with my mother and step-mother to keep the entire dump-episode a secret from The Black Widow and from my Father. I still want to throw up when I think how horrified my dad would be that part of his son is laying in the dump. I threw my brother away. I can't think of another ending. I guess there isn't one. I wish I could tell Gregg all of this mess. I wish I could call him up and hear him laugh at me. But mostly, I wish I hadn't thrown my brother in the dump.

My brother died September 7th 2003.  It was sudden and a complete shock.  Heart failier, 90% complete blockage at 39.  He had a wife and a baby and a dog.  His wife and baby are doing well, Liza is almost four now and a bit stubborn and tempermental.  She is the spitting image of my brother.  His wife has remarried a lovely man who loves Liza to bits.  His dog went back to his original owners.  My brother was a marathon runner.  Would run with his dog every day.  Tenakee, a siberian husky, had eyes only for Gregg.  Tenakee was lost and confused for a while and became too difficult for Gregg's Widow to handle.  But....sounds like he is doing well now, sounds like my brother found him a replacement, sounds like Tenakee might just pull through!  The following was written by Tenakee's new caretaker:

On the Run: The Tenakee Training Regimen
http://www.aspentimes.com/article/20060713/NEWS/107130040&SearchID=73253681014163
 
By Joel Stonington
July 13, 2006
 
I'm taking care of a 6-year-old husky named Tenakee.
 
He's sort of a bad boy. When he doesn't want to do something he goes
deaf, and he gets a bit talkative when he really wants his ears
scratched. He's a smart puppy. I like him.
 
So I've been taking him running. As a big dog, he really needs to get
out as much as possible. A 10-mile hike would maybe tire him out for
about half a day. So I run with him as fast as I can in order to get
him good and tired, which rarely happens.
 
Lately, I've been thinking that I might be getting more out of the
running sessions than he does because really, it's me keeping up with
him. What I've realized is that he might be the best training partner
I could have.
 
Here's the deal. I wake up between 6 and 7 in the a.m. This is to his
credit. If I didn't have to tire him out I would still be in bed
snoozing. He runs around the house howling and stretching out. I put
on the collar and leash, and off we go.
 
It's pretty much guaranteed that he'll go out too fast. I'm OK with
that because it gives me an advantage later. He's like that
15-year-old who sprints out at the start of a 10-miler and finds zero
energy around a mile and a half.
 
I start out at Tenakee's trot speed. Until about a week ago, I
couldn't keep up with him if he knocked it up to a doggy canter, but
all that has changed. So after about 10 minutes, I kick into his
canter pace. It's still not a gallop - he could still kick my butt
whenever he wanted to - but moving up to cantor pace is a significant
achievement.
 
Anyway, I've submitted the idea to the patent office. It's going to be
called the Tenakee Training Regimen, and I'm convinced it's going to
sweep the nation.
 
Just like tae bo.

Omygod!  I am so tired.  Every night I think, "I Haaaave to write!".  And then the dishes, or the baby, and now more often...sleep.  I need soooo much sleep.  When I wake up in the morning, I think, "how am I going to do this day? I can't get my brain out of sleep land!".  And then there has been this irritability.  Irrational and passionate.  Nothing is funny, everything is significant.  I am like on perpetual pms, hmmmph.  I am also nautious.  Then I threw up my lunch.  Then I made an apt. with my doctor.  Peed in a cup.  Alex took me.  Yes!  the sperm pierced the egg, it attached, and ... I am pregnant.  Eight weeks.  She's figuring out which sex she wants to be this week.  I see doctor next week.  Yippeee!  Now I must sleep some more.  Goodnight.

My little boy walked across the kitchen floor today. He picked up one unsteady chubby foot after another heading for my outstretched arms and landed in my lap where he gave me a tiny hug before he demanded, "boob!" and started pulling up my shirt. I was simeltaneoulsly filled with so much pride, joy, delight that I felt wet tears on my cheeks. I was also filled such a powerful sensation of wanting to hold my hands up in the air and yell, "Stop! This is going by too fast, I want to spend more time savoring every nuance, every moment, every new eyelash!" But I just nursed him and then fed him dinner and then took him for a walk to the beach to try to cool off. He dug is feet into the sand and let me bury them with wet watery muck, he splashed in the tide pools and then cried when he rubbed grit into his eyes. We walked back, my little man snuggled securely on my back pointing at birds and flowers along the way. We took a bath together, rinsing the beach off our skins. I put his damp dewey body into his little white onsie and nursed him to sleep while he cuddled and hitched a leg over my still plump mommy tummy. Now I watch as his mouth makes sucking motions in his sleep. I look at him, still tiny, but trying with all his might to touch all four corners of the bed. It is difficult for me to seperate him from the mewling puppy he was a year ago at this time. He sleeps in the same position, his chin is still plump and round with the little dimple puckering in the middle. His lashes are still dark and his mouth still curves into a contented looking smile. I imagine this odd feeling will only increase when he is two, and six and seventeen and twenty-three. I then think of those waddling steps of the afternoon. And I pray very hard. I pray like I am in battle. I pray that my tiny walker will continue to take steps, that they will become strong and purposeful. I pray that he will run and skip. I pray that his feet will grow calouses to protect the tender insides. I pray that he will walk tall, with a little bit of a bounce to his step. I pray that he will always walk. Even if it takes him away from me. I pray that he will know that I will be with him every step that his feet make, whether they are tiny and chubby or old and yellowed, and that no matter how far those feet take him, he can always walk back to me and I will always be smiling and clapping my hands, ready to fold him into my outstretched arms.

We had to ask for a siding credit cause the siding is recalled. Everything else on inspection was fabulous. So... Realtor called and said that she, "didn't get laughed out of the room." when she gave the seller our request. They have two days to respond. Arrgh. For an instant gratification type of girl that I am, buying a house really causes me to chew my cuticles down to the bone. Are we going to be moving in August? What if we don't get the house? Will Jane still take over the lease? Will we start the process all over again? Will there be another house that is right for us that we can afford? Will our parents get sick of the back and forth and back out? Oh, the drama! Plus...I have already painted and decorated in my mind, I believe we are already living there. Well, it will all be worth it in the end, and we will have finally joined the investment brigade. Keep rubbing Buddah's tummy! Updates on Wednesday. Right now in full on event planner mode, instead of writing, I am glue-gunning dried wheat onto glass vases and tieing up cutlery in bandanas, buying up baskets in the shape of chickens and funky old chairs from the local thrift store, and cooking up a storm. Glad to have a big distraction.

1. I love the way you peed right when they took you out of my tummy. 2. I love that you wanted to eat right away. 3. I love that you let daddy help you learn to nurse cause I was too drugged. 4. I love that your first word was mommy. 5. I love that your second word was daddy. 6. I love that your third word was Kitty. 7. I love that your fourth word was Boob. 8. I love that you wrinkle your nose and grin when you do something new and challenging. 9. I love that in the middle of an intense problem with your blocks, you look up and smile at me, as if you are just checking to make sure I am witnessing your problem solving skills. 10. I love how you wake up in the middle of the night and say, "mama". 11. I love that when I ask you for a Jack Kiss, you open your little chubby arms and give me a big hug and an open mouth kiss. 12. I love how you love the kitty. 13. I love how you talk from the moment you wake till the moment you sleep. 14. I love that you are so sweet, when you accidentally hurt me, and I flinch, you cry. 15. I love how you are smitten with your older 16 month old friend, Gracie. 16. I love how you love to swing, and how you giggle and giggle. 17. I love that you like to watch me cook. 18. I love that you would rather be next to me than anywhere else. 19. I love how excited you get when we go see the ducklings, and you scream, "DUCKY!" at the top of your lungs once we turn into the ducky driveway. 20. I love how you fall asleep when you are nursing, when your eyes get heavier and heavier and you try to keep them open, but finally you loose the battle. 21. I love how you insist on feeding yourself with an adult spoon, and how your get totally covered in whatever you are shoving in your mouth. 22. I love how you delight in the bath; splashing, slurping, playing with the toys and how you never want to get out of the bathtub. 23. I love how you HATE a buger in your nose so much that it will ruin your day until you get it out. 24. I love how you blow air out your mouth to try to get the buger out of your nose. 25. I love how you love yogurt so much that you will eat ANYTHING coated in it. 26. I love how you will only eat freshly made foods and turn your nose up at frozen foods. 27. I love how you cry when your daddy leaves for work. 28. I love how you wake up between me and daddy, and you look at me and 'hoo' then flip your body and yell, "Daddy! Haaaiiii!". 29. I love how you love popsicles, and pretend to share by popping them in daddy's mouth for a half a second and then grabbing it right back to eat some more. 30. I love how you snore. 31. I love how you sleep on your back with your legs and arms spread as wide as possible, with no thought to anyone else's space needs. 32. I love how when I wash your hair, you have a natural mowhak the next day. 33. I love that your hair is so blond, it is yellow. 34. I love that you love playing on the beach so much that you scream all the way home cause you didn't want to leave. 35. I love that you won't let anyone else hold you but me and daddy, selfish of me, but I do love it. 36. I love that you laugh all day long. 37. I love that when you make me and daddy laugh, you laugh more. 38. I love that you giggle and smile when daddy hugs mommy. 39. I love that you love to sit forward in your carseat and how you lift your little chin so you can look out the window. 40. I love how you fall asleep on daddy's shoulder when he walks you back and forth. 41. I love how daddy is the only one who can make you sleep when you feel sick. 42. I love that you only wanted to walk in baby group when you saw every one else walk, and unless you are there competing, you have no interest in walking. 43. I love that you say "Haaaiiiii"all the time. 44. I love that you think everything is "pretty". 45. I love how much energy you have and how you love to play. 46. I love your big grey sparkley eyes. 47. I love that I never want to be even a room away from you. 48. I love how you try to climb everything. 49. I love that when you fall, you raise your hands and call me, "mama". 50. I love that I get to be a witness to the beginning of your little life. Love, Mommy

Today we gave a check to an escrow company. I have never written a $5000.00 check before. We have 'the inspection' tomorrow. This is where a contractor type comes to the home that you have bid correctly for and tells you what is wrong with it. THEN, we take that information, process it, and tell the seller what she needs to fix. The seller then says, yes or no. We are counting on a Yes, since there is only one thing wrong that Alex (My spouse and another contractor type) could find, and that was the re-called heaters. So, hopefully, she will agree to fix them or give us money to fix them. Then we will wait a few weeks till the closing date and we will sign many large checks for the down payment. I think it will all go smoothly, seems to be working well for everyone. I told my Landlord today the 'bad news for her' and softened it by bringing her a tenant to finish out our lease. She was thrilled (I knew that the seller of our new home is the x lover of my current land lord, they owned the house together then my landlord gave our new house to her old lover in their 'dissolution settlement') when I told her which house it was, and seemed genuinely pleased that we were to be the new owners. She told me that the owner of the house was a 'good friend' of hers. She actually said, 'Well, everyone wins then, good." I am much relieved as we do live on an ISLAND and I don't want to piss anyone off because they are not likely to forget it. My friend Vanessa who is a Feng Shui (sp?) consultant, is going to do an 'offsite consultation' and give us all the money envelopes and blessing/rituals we need to perform before moving in. I'm hoping this will bless us even more than we have been. Then, we want to paint it bright red. It is a bit gray and misty here in the fall and winter, so I want to be looking at something cheery. Oh, I am so thrilled that our families decided we were finally responsible enough to help with such a big investment. Now, we just have a few more thousand to scrounge for by the end of the month for closing costs. I think we'll make it and if we don't, well....dear old dad will just have to reach deeper in his pockets. Keep rubbing the Buddah's tummy, think good thoughts and pray hard for a good inspection.

We extended till Sunday, this is so irritating. Don't know how I used to do this with auditions on a daily or weekly basis. Think goooooooood thoughts, pray, or rub your Budda's belly for us! C We put an offer on another house. It has walls, and floors and new carpet. It has a laundry room, three bedrooms (quite small, but THREE!). It has a stove and a dishwasher, and a little bathroom. It is called a Rambler. It doesn't quite 'ramble' it is just too succinct. We both like it. Jack loved crawling around on the new carpet. We want to paint it bright red. We hope we can. there is an acre of land about it. full of blackberries and trees of all sorts. Lots of exploring for a little boy. The realtor (the new one, we fired the other one after discovering that she KNEW that the septic on the first house we bid on had FAILED and didn't tell us!) said the owner was quite happy to get the offer. The realtor has a good feeling. So do I, but after so many auditions with no call backs, it is hard to hope. We find out tomorrow if she counters. Will keep you posted. Hopeful, once again, homeowner.

I took my 13 month old to the park this morning.  It was sunny out, and we have done the beach about five times already this week, so I thought maybe both of us could use a change.  I remember my mom taking me and my brother to this great park with tall swings and big cedar trees and picnik tables sprinkled all over.  I loved that park, my brother and I would see who could swing the highest and of course he always won.  So, off I go, trying to re-create some good memories from my past.  Even though Jack is much too young to use the big kid swings and he doesn't have a sibling (yet) , how can you go wrong at a park?  Well, I will tell you.  

First off, I practically just rolled out of bed. Shower?  I think I had one the day before last but couldn't be sure. I struggled to put on a wife beater and some cargos, AND I pulled my hair back with a scrunchy (yes, I still have scrunchies) and exposed my gray roots.  I thought, who will see me?  I am just going to play on the swings with my son!  Secondly, I didn't so much dress my son as I threw on what I could reach that was relatively clean, which meant; black leggings and a blue and red baseball shirt.  He still had cherries stuck in his hair from his breakfast that he tipped on to his head and I don't think I'd cleaned his ears in about three weeks.  

I pull myself and him out of our Ford station wagon that hasn't seen a car wash, well, ever, and I try not to let the garbage that covers the floor, tumble to the pavement as I yank Jack out of his car seat.  I hoist him up on my voluminous hip and slam the door.  It is a full 30 steps before I look up from the grass and gravel path heading toward the play ground and what I see stops my heart.  

Mommies.  A lot of mommies.  A lot of mommies and a lot of babies.  A lot of trim, crisply dressed, smooth haired, lotioned and outfit appropriate mommies.  All their babies had on sun bonnets and I am sure UV treated outfits that coordinated.  All the little ones also had on shoes, which makes sense as the park is full of wood chips that could splinter little tender toes.  Jack NEVER wears shoes.  First of all, he curls his toes so much when I try to wedge them on his feet that they won't fit, and if I am lucky enough to get them on his feet, he just pulls at them until he frees his little piggies and the shoes go flying into the abyss of the floor of the car.  But had I remembered the wood chips, I would have tried with the shoes.  So, not only do I look like a jiggly homeless mom, Jack looks like an untended unkept little urchin with no shoes.  I try to 'not care' and press on toward the swings which are busy with little coifed and shod shiny haired cherubs.  

Miraculously, one of the baby swings was abandoned and I slipped jack into the black rubber cup  that would keep him safe and started pushing him. He LOVES the swing!  He was laughing and 'wheeing' and pointing, totally cute.  Around me the mommies were all talking to their little ones, at first I didn't pay attention to the individual words, I was just so shocked that all the mommies had the same cadence to their speach when talking to the children.  Jack and I were having a quiet morning.  We talk a lot sometimes and then others we just hang out together being kind of silent.  We communicate with looks and touches and giggles.  Makes me smile just to think of how he quietly tries to figure out a problem with a toy and then will look up and smile at me, knowing I am right there watching.  

Then the 'mommie speak' started to come clear next to me.  The mommy with the blond bob and the kaki capris and crisp white (WHITE, not Gray) t-shirt  was talking incessently to her blond flower-clad little one.  "Good Gretta, that's a gooood, push on the black swing with the chains!  Are you swinging on the black plastic seat going higher and higher?  Is your flowered hat flapping in the wind when you swing on the black plastic seat higher and higher?

Odd way to talk to a kid, I thought.  Oh well, to each her own.  We got off the swing and away from  blond bobbed mommy as quickly as possible and went over to the 'springed  section'.  there are about five large springs with different vehicles (motorcycles, cars, bycicles and even a dragon) that the kid sits on and bounces backward and foward like a traditional rocking horse.   I put jack on the motorcycle.  He loved it, grabbed on to the handlebars and heaved his weight back and forth.  I smiled.  Until I heard the mommy with the long shiny black hair and the Eileen Fisher Linnen 'casual capri/crumpled shirt' ensamble continue to talk to her little one, "Good Job Madison!  Are you bouncing on the green dragon?  Did that make you laugh?  Did bouncing on the green dragon while watching the baby on the red motorcycle, 'vroom vroom' make you laugh?"  And I heard more from the corner mommie wearing Seven Jeans, Keds and an v-neck Orange t-shirt, "Good job Jillian, you found your hidden snack!  You found your secret crackers and fresh orange juice sippy snack!  You found your secret snack in the observation tower!  Are you eating your special secret crackers while looking through the binoculars of the blue observation tower?"  and Then Eileen Fisher mommie started talking to Jack, "Are you riding the red motorcycle?  Vroom Vroom!  Are you bouncing back and foward on the big red motorcycle while your little bare feet press down on the foot pedals, Look Madison, the little baby is riding on the motorcycle, vroom vroom!"

Omygod, they are trying to teach me how to parent.  They think that I am not talking to my son enough, they are 'modeling' how to parent for me.  I am sure that in their eyes, I must seem like a homeless young mom who has no idea what she's doing.   Before Eileen Fisher mom could get in another 'Vroom Vroom", I grabbed Jack from the motorcycle and headed to my car.  

Unbelievable.  Those moms have no idea that my little 13 month old has about a 25 word vocabulary and LOVES to read books more than anything in the world so far.  I wonder how well their little one's talk.  They sure were silent while playing, maybe they just don't have room in between the 'mommy monolouges' to form words and express opinions.  Whatever the reason, we couldn't get out of Stepford Park fast enough.  Tomorrow, we'll go to the beach again where Jack can get dirty and not only go bare foot, but take all his clothes off if he wants.  He can get sandy and disgusting and splash in the tide pools while grabbing a rock and showing it to me while saying, 'pretty' because we leave enough silence in our relationship that we can actually communicate.

http://www.chihuly.com/installations/public/Art/chinookB.html Chihuly is an amazing artist, his work is all over the world. The woman whom I will be catering for is one of his apprentices. Dale Chihuly was born in Tacoma Washington, in 1941. He received his M.S. in sculpture in 1967 from the University of Wisconsin, where he studied glassblowing with Harvey Littleton. In 1969 he established the Glass Department at the Rhode Island School of Design, where he taught until 1983. In 1983 Chihuly returned to his native Pacific Northwest where he continued to develop his own work at the Pilchuck Glass School, which he had helped to found in 1971. Throughout the 1970's , influenced by the great glassblowing tradition of Murano, Chihuly experimented with the team approach to glassblowing. Working with a team of master glassblowers and assistants has enabled him to produce architectural glass art of a scale and quantity unimaginable working alone or with only one assistant. After an automobile accident in 1976 in which he lost the sight in his left eye, Chihuly relinquished the gaffer (chief glassblower) position and turned over that position to William Morris. Utilizing Morris' substantial talent and physical strength, Chihuly developed the large scale, multi-colored forms known as the MACCHIA series (Italian for "spotted.") In the early 1980's, Chihuly and Morris worked extensively on the SEAFORM series, undulating shell-like forms within forms. They also began the SOFT CYLINDER series, which combined elements of the earlier Basket and Cylinder series. In 1986, Chihuly developed the new PERSIAN series with former R.I.S.D. student Martin Blank as gaffer. In 1988, he began the highly ornate VENETIAN series with master Italian glassblower Lino Tagliapietra as gaffer. In the 1990's, while continuing to work intermittently on his previous series, Chihuly has turned his attention towards large-scale architectural glass art installations. Particularly dramatic are his 3-dimensional art glass Chandeliers, which gained international acclaim in 1996, when his two-year architectural glass art project "Chihuly Over Venice" culminated with the hanging of fourteen Chandeliers at various sites in Venice. Most recently a hybrid of the Chihuly Chandelier series has appeared in the form of wall SCONCES. Dale Chihuly is now widely recognized as the world's premier glass artist and has been the subject of many books, critical essays and PBS specials. Chihuly glass sculpture can be found in over 150 major museums, including the Hokkaido Museum of Modern Art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Museum of Modern Art, the Louvre, the Victoria and Albert Museum and the Whitney Museum.

Well, we put an offer on the shack. And somewhere in the process we fell in love wiith the property, potential and even the shell of a house despite the lack of floors and walls. We had an army of support behind us, and with that support came an army of advice. All of our Generals told us to bid low. I wanted to give a conservative bid of 10 grand below. That was too much for Alex. So we went low. We did. There is another offer on the house. Probably not a low offer. We think we lost the house. I am quite out of sorts. My lovely husband is dancing around our rented kitchen holding jack and singing Ooo-Ga-Cha-Ka at the top volume from the radio and his lungs. Jack is squeeling. My dad, who refused to give us advice on our offer is now telling us that we offered 'WAAAAAAy too low!' Well, that would have been good advice YESTERDAY when we came to your house with the paperwork and asked your advice! If we need to learn our own lessons, don't say, "I told you so" and grind salt into our wounds. Let us learn our lesson and encourage us that there will be more opportunities! Right now, I feel like we lost the best opportunity of a life time. Feels kind of like that movie I auditioned for where the director wrote the role for me and then Network made me do a call back because my shirt was 'too square' and then hired a SKINNY girl! I hated loosing that part. I hate loosing this house. Yeah, we have five hours left, but I think, I feel, I sense, that we are out of the game. Just feels gross and don't know what to do with this sad sad feeling. The good thing is that Me and Alex did it together. We learned that I am a better poker player, I am able to compromise and maybe next time we will find a middle place that we are both uncomfortable with. We are definitely a team, and once again we proved it. So...what's a house when you have your husband and son dancing in your kitchen to 'Hooked on a Feeling''?

http://images-eu.amazon.com/images/P/B00006SFK2.01.LZZZZZZZ.jpg

I've been nostalgic this week.  Maybe it's the hot breaze blowing through the pines that makes me feel a yearning for Los Angeles.  Maybe it is the fact that I am NOT pregnant which means I can still keep working on finding my once delicious wasteline, or ... maybe I just miss part of me that is firmly fixed in the past.  

I don't miss the business of acting.  I will always miss acting, but; oh, how I hated the administering-your-career part of 'the business'.  All those endless mailings of my own mug to people who'd take one look at my slightly rounded face and pitch them into the old circular file.  Or those nausiating self promoting post cards I would create while in some half assed stage production of some ultra meaningful and significant writer from the 70's.  I ESPECIALLY don't miss 'drop-off's', that's where you take your head shot into the casting director's office and usually get snubbed by their 20 year old receptionist.  And I really, REALLY don't miss having discussions with other actors, cause they always go like this:

Me:
Hi!  How are you?  What is going on, I haven't seen you in so long!?
Them:
OmygodIamdoingso greaaat (imagine a upward lilt to the last word of every sentance)!  Iwasjustinthemost AMAAAAZIIING play, and Harvy Weinstein cametoseeit? IjustgotcalledintoPassionsAgaaain? So...theyHAVEtohiremeONEofthesetimes,i'veONLYauditionedforthemEIGHTtimes! MyINDIEfilmisinSUNDANCE?omygod,I amgoing,can'twait. MyNATIONALgotPickedupAGAIN,THankGod,totallyNEEDtheMONEY,youknow? And...don't tell anyone, but I fucked my manager? anditwasAWFUL!?So now I have to get a new one, WHOrepresent'sYOUuuu???
Me:
Ummm, I don't have a manager and I haven't fucked anybody recently but I did read a really good book last week....(trailing off in the face of a blank stare)
THEM
OmyGod! AREyouAUDITIONING for COLDcreekFARM? Ireadit? just IN CASE Igotcalledin? buthaven'tfinishedit yet.  Omygod,there is Ben,HE is sooooooofine?
Me:
I'll be right back.

I don't miss the neighborhoods I lived in, none of the nine neighborhoods I lived in from Hollywood to the Valley to Downtown could hold a candle to the community I am in now.   I must have keept moving to try to find a place where I fit in, or at least was on nodding terms with my neighbors.

I don't miss the traffic.  Nor do I miss the hot concrete that covers everything.  Nor do I miss driving from audition to audition in the sweltering heat.  

I certainly don't miss my money jobs, especially those times when I had to be a personal assistant to people with overly inflated ego's and a need to hold court and treat me as their personal servant.  Nope, done with other people's laundry (except my husband and children's--for I AM a really good house wife).

Who would miss all that?   I DO; however, I miss being the fun-girl who is invited to parties.  I'm not normally fun at parties.  Kind of shy and akward.  But give me a splash of the bubbley (or a bottle, let's be honest) and off I go being inappropriate with men, telling penis jokes so the whole neighborhood can hear, airing people's nasty secrets but with such charm and humor, that everyone would laugh and even hope to be my next target. 

 I often made everyone take off their shoes and swing dance to Cherry Poppin Daddies (waaay after they were made popular by the movie Swingers) and then lead a whole group of emaciated actresses to Denny's where I'd make them eat pancakes and real butter (they all probably do some sort of purging..but I tried)  While shoveling delicious and forbidden carbs into their mouths, they let me make fun of their bad relationships and their too-white capped teeth and their knobby bodies that 'REAL men won't fuck'.  AND no matter what, they all just kept begging for MORE!    I miss wearing flirty skirts (oh, I WANT my flat stomach back) and talking about sex so all the men would think me wild.  (most were extremely disappointed to find that my real personality is quite nerdy, I am into the missionary position, and I really do spend a major portion of my time reading).  I would go home with phone numbers in my pockets and laughter in my ears.  I felt...well....full. 

I don't miss the morning after.  Waking with some random man I titilated with sophomoric jokes was 'super' embarassing, I just want to have my coffee and finish the last chapter of my novel and instead had to figure out weird 'one night stand' etiquitte.  I don't miss the hangover, could take me a whole day, and sometimes two, or three (let's be honest, we had the beginning of a raging problem)  to feel human again.  

Don't miss the after party lonliness/depression that settled in my bones whether some one was under my sheets with me or not.  Yes, that was the worst.  To be 'totally popular' and have 'everyone' love me for a couple hours, to practically be carried on all their drunk shoulders, and then go right back to my complete and utter lonliness...I don't miss that at all.  Yeah, I guess while getting nostalgic, I forgot about the 'comedown'.

I guess I just yearn for that little tiny bit because that is the only tiny bit of love I felt in that town.  But I guess that now I am loved the way I was frantically searching for.  I may seem a bit more boring from the outside.  I do lots of laundry and take my son to the beach and to swim classes and play groups.  My husband and I long for his two days off all week so we can all three go play together in the city.  I clean lots of baby messes and pick up a never ending dibris of toys strewn from bedroom to living area, I get together with my two friends on the island about once a month and we talk as fast as we can, trying to get everythin into our 45 minute walk. Most of my time is full of long solitary walks with my son on my back looking at the Puget Sound and the Sandy beaches and cliffs.  I think a lot here.  My brain is less noisy.  I think about how lucky I am to be loved despite my mommy tummy, despite my lack of cute shoes and a current hair cut.  I am loved BECAUSE I read and I GET to love these two amazing males in my life as much as I want.  

Hmmm...I guess I really DON"T miss those parties, 'like, at all!'. Well,  Maybe the shoes and the fluttery skirts, but just a bit.

Well, we had fun trying! Now for another month of checking the consistensy of my bodily fluids and my waking temperature. Wish us luck! Maybe I will be able to loose that other 30 lbs of baby fat before I start packing it on again. And...as much as we want more babies RIGHT NOW, it will be nice to have more time with Jack, and if this house deal goes through, well....I will be able to work on it instead of whine and waddle around being miserable.

If you have a problem with discharge or are queasy regarding the 'female cycle' stop now, this is not for you. It is a possibility. We are trying. I am at a 42 day cycle. My cycle is usually 33 days. It means that there could be a four and a half week old embryo doing some serious cell division in my still pudgy tummy. I know it is four and a half weeks old, because my crunchy neighbor knew we were working on our second baby and knew I wanted to get implanted as soon as possible since I am FORTY!. She gave me a book called Taking Charge of Your Fertility. Ohmygod, I never knew! And they sure didn't teach girls about cervical fluid and ovulation cycles in fith grade Health class! I honestly thought that there was something wrong with me when I had tons of rubbercement like discharge. But, no....that is apparently very very good, well for conceiving. You see the sperm can live in the more viscous jelly for up to five (FIVE), (5) days! So you can have sex several days before the egg bursts into the falopian tube and those little swimmers will just hang out around the jelly bar waiting for some action. Anyway, I was using the restroom and noticed that I did indeed have some long stringy gelatenous discharge. It was around my time for ovulation. It was also around Three in the morning. My husband had just gotten home from closing the restaurant and was doing his nightly wind down in front of his Play Station two. I came out of the bathroom and interrupted Laura Croft's bouncing breasts trying to smash some sort of scaley beast, and said, "If there was ever a good time to concieve, i.e. have sex, now would be it.". So we hopped on to the office floor and spent some delightful moments laughing about conceptual sex as we were copulating. Seven minutes later, Alex was back on his joy stick fighting anphibians and I was tucked in to bed with my feet elevated. Ah, married romance. Stay tuned for updates!

So...We move from L.A. to Vashon Island in the Pugot Sound. We give up our limping acting dreams and our lucrative restaurant jobs to give our son a more sane environment in which to grow. We fell in love while on the ferry over from Seattle. When we stepped off the ferry on to our new home, both of us were choked up, but embarassed about it so it wasn't too mushy or significant. We have flourished here, which is new for us. In los angeles, spinning our wheels was a good place for us. We were usually broke, depressed, and begging rides from overutilized friends to get to auditions we hoped would solve all our problems but never did. Alex has a job on the Island at an amazing restaurant that just opened, they love him and he loves them and already he has had a raise and constant compliments. he is able to use all his brains and contribute and even is getting known for his singing ability. Apparently, he sings happy birthday to everyone on the Island as well as having musical theatre song downs with the local Musical lovers. Everyone I meet asks me if my husband is the 'handsome one who sings'. We tried to buy a house when we first got here, but it was too difficult to get a loan for a manufactured home, and frankly, it just seemed a bit, well...icky. A tin home built in the bottom of a bowl with dog paths in the yard and a broken down swing set. Hmmmm... potential but it is what it is...a manufacutred home. We also had the opportunity to build a house in a community of 19. Our down payment would have been our sweat equity. Me and Jack would have spent 30 hours a week with strangers that would be our neighbors, painting, nailing, and, well, whatever else you do to build a home, only we couldn't make a profit cause it was a low income deal. So we said no to that opportunity. Just as we finally got the last picture hung in our quaint rental, I found our house. It is perfect. 1.5 acres, great neighborhood (close to beach and my best friends and neighbors whom we plan to do a goat-share with, but that is another story) 1700 square feet, new foundation, new roof, new windows, and TOTALLY GUTTED. My husband's parents are builders in Alaska and keep badgering us to buy property so they can come build us a home. Well, with the prices on this island climbing every month just out of our reach, we figured it would take a miracle to find the right property. It is nearly impossible to get water shares on the island, also impossible to get building permits. So, this place is perfect. There are 'good bones' as the realtor's say in their super hip lingo. i had to present it to my overworked husband who just moved us to Vashon, only to move us out of our terrible falling down rental into our cute darling rental down the street, I couldn't say, "Hey, wanna move again?" So...This is how I delicately and tactfully and sensitively posed it to him. Did I mention that I woke him up early in the morning? me Honey, are you awake? Him What do you want now? me Nothing, why? Him You are being too nice. Me (ignoring his comment) well, I found our house and dad said he would finance it so we just have to get a down payment from your parents which shouldn't be difficult and I am seven, SEVEN (I hold up seven fingers and poke him with my elbow) S E V E N Days late so I am probably pregnant. Him You are a trip. 'Morning, wanna make the biggest financial decision of your life today? Oh, yeah, I'm pregnant. Here hold the baby I need to pee.' If I didn't already have high blood pressure, I would now! Me Shall I start the coffee? My dad has offered us more help than he's offered since I needed braces. The next step was to ask Alex's parents for a whopping $30,000.00 dollars. Hi, can I have THIRTY THOUSAAAANNNDD DOLLARS? Can you imagine? But we did it. So...now we wait and see. I guess I get to say, stay tuned for more, cause I hope and think they will help us...but...there is no guarantee! Cross your fingers, pray, throw salt over your left shoulder and throw some pennies in the fountain for us. We'll keep you posted! Christi the hopeful home owner
